There is a better way to make your algorithm, this concept being to think about not just false positive and false negatives, but also to consider where the false negative is non zero and where the false positive is approximately 0. For example at 13:48 , the chance for a cheater to get 0 heads in a 5 flip is nearly zero. In this case, you don't need to further test any individual who gets 5 negatives in the first 5 flips, only further test the individuals that get heads.

By utilizing this concept, you can choose to A) use less total flips because you stop testing earlier making the test faster, or B) use the flips you saved to test suspicious players more, thereby decreasing the false positive and false negative (accuracy)

And of course you could do some quick optimization to get the best time to stop the test early within your parameters

Why can't you require someone flip more times if they did well on the first flips?

Everyone flips 10 times. Anyone who flips heads 6 or more times, they flip 20 more times. 63% of the fair players flip 10 times and 37% flip 30 times, an average of 18 flips for fair players.

Meanwhile, 92% of cheaters will flip heads 6 or more times out of 10, so nearly all of them will be subject to the "second round" of testing.

In 30 flips, 4.94% of fair players will flip 20 or more times, so you can set the 30-flip threshhold at 20 / 30. Meanwhile, cheaters get at least 20/30 heads 89.4% of the time.

Of the 92% of cheaters who are subjected to the second testing round, some started with just 6 heads in the first round and so need 14 / 20 heads in round 2 to be labeled a cheater, while some had 7, 8, 9, or 10 heads in round 1 and need fewer heads in round 2 to be labeled a cheater.

In the worst case, your cheater had only gotten 6 heads in round 1 and now needs 14/20 heads in round 2, which they achieve 78.6% of the time. Those who got 7 in the first round (a more common outcome), need at least 13 in the second round, which happens 89.8% of the time.

So I think, especially for cases where you want very high true positive rates, very low false positive rates, and the minimal number of flips, you could best achieve those results by doing a smaller number of tests to start and then do further testing on those who perform slightly above average. You could do more than two rounds of testing as well.

This has the added benefit that any excessive testing most commonly inconveniences cheaters rather than fair players.

To the people who would like to know how this is applied to the anticheat in an FPS shooter (assuming that there already exists an anticheat that detects suspicous movement.)

Let's say that an average person has hit 69/100 shots overall in the game. A beginner cheater using aim bot would most definitely get 100/100 shots. Even a garbage anticheat can pick up on it. But a smart cheater alters his/her aimbot to only hit little more than an average person, say 85/100.

The anticheat would have to have some basic boundaries for the shoot-hit ratio. But this is easily detectable. However, with every new player, the anticheat would require getting atleast 100 shots to process an accusation. This is too much time for a cheater to be discovered and banned.

- So why not just 10 shots?

If the average person hits 7/10 shots, and a cheater hits 8-9/10, we cannot make a fair margin between what counts as "lucky shots" and what is a consistent cheater. The anticheat will ban players quickly, however, not fairly.


So to make a more fair accusation, is to wait and see, but that gives more time to a cheater to ruin matches.

The easiest way this applies to games would be Chess cheaters. Chess has an easy cheating software and many players. One of the easiest ways to spot a cheater would be to check the accuracy of moves in a game. A robot would be nearly perfect in every move and would score above 90% on every move, even grandmasters will mess up sometimes or will not make a "perfect" move. But a normal person can get lucky and score above 90% sometimes. So am easy check would be to see how often they score over 90 and look for other signs of cheating and then bring the ban hammer down. I think the fact that you're trying to catch those people with cheat coins is a problem because what a cheat coin is undefined. Lets imagine that everyone is using homemade coins, and the fairness of the coins is kind of random and all over the place, and instead of cheating intentionally, some people just have coins that come up heads too frequently because of poor construction.

Now the goals change. Instead of trying to catch so many of the cheaters, now we want to define the range of what fairness means in a coin. So maybe we say a fair coin doesn't flip heads more than 55% of the time. For the time being we'll ignore coins that are weighted more to land on tails and figure that this is the player's responsibility to deal with.

So we want to design a test that finds 80% of the coins that have more than a 55% flip rate. Lets ignore false positives for now. Lets take 10 flips and then choose the number of heads that would successfully accuse 80% of the coins with over 55% flip rate. This is going to get a really high number of false positives. So then from the positives we run the same test again, such that we catch 80% of the cheat coins in that scenario and let the other 20% go. Now we repeat that process until we have under 5% false positive rate.

This means the number of trials is n. Flips is f, we do f * n trials in the worst case for a player. To test players this way, we will know the maximum proportion of the population we will need to accuse in each stage, which would be the case when all players are cheaters, so we have an idea of the worst case scenario for number of tests, which would be a function of the worst case trial times a function of the population size to the power of the number of trials. In a normal case with mixed cheaters and fair players, it would be the worst case trial times a function of the population size and the fair players to the power of the number of trials.

Now we have a general idea on how it will go down. Unfortunately, we don't catch 80% of cheaters here, we catch 80% to the power of n cheaters. So instead, we play with these numbers so that that new term "statistical power" of the first trial to the power of n equals 80% while after n trials we will have a 5% false positive rate. We can do this by increasing f, or increasing n and the statistical power.

In a real world scenario it might be best to monitor the outcome of the flips to build a database of players who need to undergo further scrutiny. So that a run of so many tests is recorded, and when it appears that there's a high enough chance that there's something fishy then they go to further trials. This could be just a threshold maybe where 30% of the fair trials would end up with a run like this. This could let the number of flips used to calculate this be really high because it has no impact on the players, just some data analysis.

This would mean that 70% of fair players would generally go untested across this period. 30% would be subject to testing, we would want to control the number of flips so that more than 80% of cheaters would be subject to testing. Then in testing the test could be more aggressive, no we only need to get the final number of cheaters to 80%, but the number of false positives only need to be about 16.7%, because if even 1/6 of the fair players tested come up as false positive, if only 30% of the fair players end up having to submit to trial, 1/6 of that is still only 5%.

The other thing about this is it can be progressive testing. Players who have coins that flip heads 55% of the time might take a lot of trials recorded playing in the population before getting pulled in for trial. On the other hand, a player who has a coin that flips heads 95% of the time will get pulled in immediately after having an unreasonable streak.

I think this would help to increase the overall fairness of the play in the population. A player with a 55% win coin will stick around longer without getting pulled in for trial. But they will have a much lower impact on the fairness of the player population. A player with a 95% win coin will get pulled out very quickly, and will have a higher impact on the fairness of the player population but for a much shorter time.

The future trials will show whether it's likely that this is random chance or whether it's consistent. This gives a way to test players that are potentially playing unfair without impacting the fairness of the game.

I would also take this one step further. It could be that a player has a decoy coin that it uses when it is called in for trial. So two things should be monitored. One is the likelihood of a cheater who has the same coin during trials. This setup will handle this situation already. The other one is the likelihood that a player is a cheater whose coin surprisingly starts to play fair when being monitored. To deal with the second situation, we can exclude the data from the trials and continue to monitor data only with other players. When that data of flips against other players hits a certain threshold, then we can straight up accuse them of cheating. So if the player with 10 heads in a row comes to trial and gets 10 tails in a row, or 50/50 heads and tails, and then goes back into the game and gets 10 more heads in a row, they're gone without another trial. Similar to the player who consistently wins 10% more often than everyone else, and again, the first player would be ejected quickly, and the second would stick around in the population for a really long time.

I think there's also one other difficulty. In a lot of games not every win is equally as valuable. Maybe you have a coin that cheats heads, an coin that cheats tails, and a fair coin. If a player flips a heads coin when the stakes are really high, chooses to flip an unlucky coin an equal number of times when the stakes are low, and uses the fair coin the rest of the time, it will be impossible to detect this player without also considering the value of the outcome of a successful or unsuccessful flip.

It should be noted that this test would absolutely fail to do anything in more complex scenarios. I often see people asking why you cant just use statistics or math to catch cheaters since they are winning more right? But here are some issues with that:
-The example game is a pure game of chance, so this would only really work for gambling games like roulette or something, things you have no influence over other than cheating somehow. But if we would try to move this to any other game even just basic poker suddently player skill gets involved. A player that knows the game more will be able to play it better and therefore have a higher winrate over someone who just randomly plays cards, so we can't just assume fixed win chances that we can compare against. (This is the main reason why anti cheat sofware searches for suspicious programs instead of checking how well you play).
-The model does not at all factor in tactics used by cheaters to avoid getting caught. As you mentioned we had to assume a 75% winrate for cheaters, but what if they use 60% or 51%, what if they change that value every time. What if they only use the cheated coin when they need it to win and otherwise use a normal one?

The problem with this approach is that skill isn't taken into consideration. In first person shooters for instance, the rate of success of any one player would be heavily biased by the difference in skill of them vs their opponent. Since that difference is impossible to know prior to knowing if we're talking about a cheater, this method isn't viable.

I think the best solution is to compromise by having a higher false positive test, and then do another, more rigorous test with the smaller group of accused blobs. That was you can end up with a lower number of false positives overall, but still be expedient

@ 3:50 "With a one in four chance of accusing an innocent blob"... doesn't make any sense. How do you arrive at a 75% chance the blob is cheating after throwing two heads? Or 87.5% after three heads? Would one heads imply the blob is 50% likely to cheat? An event with probability P doesn't imply a chance of (1-P) of foul play. By that logic, lottery winners can be labeled cheats with high confidence: the person winning a one in a million shot is a cheater 99.9999% of the time. You carry that line of reasoning pretty far, saying you want to lower that number as much as possible, saying we're 95% confident we caught a cheater after five times heads.

Later you admit that we need to make assumptions about the prevalence and the method of cheating before we can calculate these chances, but you never revisit the unfounded guesses you presented with confidence in the first half of the video.

It's the type of error that has had people convicted of crimes they didn't commit and is also known as the Prosecutor's Fallacy. P(A|B)!=P(B|A) or applied to this case: the chance that a player, given they're fair, throws 2 heads != the chance that a player, given they've thrown two heads, is fair.

This is a common study in cyber security. More secure usually means more false positives, while less security usually means more false negatives. More security also means more complicated interface while less security means less trust. Secure passwords and MFA (mult-factor authentication) are harder to manage (such as sending an OTP to your phone) and people love to use the same password across multiple systems. This creates what's called a single point of failure. This subject alone counts for 1 college credit hour!

The threshold of tolerance is often also guided by consequences.
You would expect the tolerance for false positives for murder convictions to be lower than for simple video game cheating for example. (unfortunately as we have seen from DNA/other exonerations it's not. Despite evidence that at least 5% of convicted murderers turn out to be innocent their convictions and sentences continue to be upheld. Courts/governors apparently are comfortable sleeping at night even knowing that for every one of those innocents there is a murderer still on the loose)

I submitted [this approach] + [a control procedure] as a way of detecting cheaters in online gaming: if you think a player is cheating, you keep a track record of their positives.
every time a "cheater" (false positive) is marked, you add a point to their record.
blatant cheaters were easy to spot: auto aim, flying, teleporting... those were instantly banned.
the trick was catching the slippery ones.
cheaters will keep on cheating, because it provides a feedback to them... they cheat, they win, they get away with it, they keep cheating.
with the tracking system, you only really ever target those players for which the record is suspiciously high, effectively screening out false positives.
one is random, two is a coincidence, three is a pattern.... well, with this system you track patterns

I spent my life as a software engineer. I also have a degree in math. And one thing I learned over the years is that it is always better not to do any math when there is no need for it.
I think an easier and more effective way to ensure no cheater ever gets away with it while guaranteeing no fair player ever gets falsely accused would be to test everyone's coin before allowing the flipping contest to commence, and only permit those who brought fair coins to compete. The problem with this contest is that it permits the players to bring their own coins instead of providing a set of uniform coins for them to use. I don't think anyone would play this game knowing that some people may bring biased coins to the event. In fact, I wonder if anybody would show up with a coin that doesn't have two heads on it, knowing that. Thus, everyone would flip nothing except heads and every round is a gigantic field-wide tie ball game that would never end. Hence, the probability that you get false positives = true positives = false negatives = true negatives = p-value = EV = 0 since the number of players will always be zero. There is a 100% probability that the contest will be a flop, however.

The most accurate test for any contest of this nature, presuming you manage to find people willing to play, is to simply accuse them all. You'll achieve 100% of the cheaters caught and falsely accuse < 5% no problem. There exists nowhere on Earth where more than 5% of the population are dumb enough to bring a fair coin to this game. Plus, getting it wrong won't matter because anyone stupid enough to bring a fair coin is worthy of ridicule & suspicion anyway. There exists no reputation there that is vulnerable to damage by false accusations. Their reputation was discarded the moment they decided to use a fair coin. No point worrying about trying to minimize it, it's naturally almost at zero already. Besides, they are easily identifiable visually. They're the same ones who can't figure out how to flip the coin.


Correct conclusion...no math required.


For a game like this, you're analyzing it backwards. You should be trying to detect the fair coins not the cheaters. It's a smaller pile to sift through. And on that note, being more serious, you probably can get better results if you also eliminate those who are clearly not cheating from the equation before making your analysis and educated guess. You are thinning the herd only at the front of it. You'll do better if you take out all the stragglers first. Nobody cheats for the purpose of losing. You haven't worked that into it at all. I can't help but believe it would help to start by looking only at the potentially suspicious ones, not simply the winners. Work your analysis on a reduced subset of the starting group so you can dig deeper into the pile and access more of them using the same percentages. Since you slice away a portion of almost exclusively true negatives before you begin, you decrease the probability of false positives and increase the probability of true positives overall because more of the people you end up accusing turn out to be cheaters. It also might allow you to try a more aggressive method on the ones who remain. If you can eliminate a significant percentage from the bottom, i.e., the ones who are obviously not cheating, then you can be more aggressive with the rest of them. Particularly with a dataset that contains mostly fair players, as probably one ought to expect to be the case nearly every time in realistic situations. I think you are mistakenly presuming the cheaters are distributed uniformly in the dataset, at least potentially. I think you'd catch more cheaters probabilistically if you focused in on only that portion of the distribution that is most likely to have the cheaters in it. Certainly, in the group you slice away, there could exist a couple of cheaters who did terrible despite having a biased coin, and you'll miss them, but they are also the ones whose cheating had no impact on the contest, and the probability says they won't likely even end up there so only a tiny fraction of the cheaters will get missed there. They've already been sorted out by Lady Luck. The true positives & false positives tend to come from the upper end of the distribution where there are more cheaters drawing more scrutiny. The true negatives & false negatives tend to exist in the bottom end where fewer cheaters end up and those that do aren't worth scrutinizing. The true negatives & false positives tend to come from the bottom where mostly fair players are found. The false negatives & true positives mostly come from the top since cheaters tend to perform better.

Maybe the way to look at it is: if the best fair player wins, then the contest must have been fair, else it wasn't. You don't really need to catch all the cheaters unless you want to punish them. All you really need to do is identify the best performing fair player. It's important to notice that any cheater who was beaten by any fair player did not impact the outcome. They are equally as irrelevant as are every fair player who was beaten by some other fair player. Also, no player, cheater or fair, influenced the performance of any other participant. Everyone who lost to some fair player could have never showed up to play and the outcome would be the same. The fastest most bulletproof solution to this problem is an iterative one not a statistical one.
1. Accuse the 1st place winner
2. If they cheated then disqualify them, move everyone else up a place, and return to step 1. Otherwise, you have found the contest winner and need not look further at anyone else. The first false positive you encounter is the winner. Doesn't matter how many cheaters were discovered or left undiscovered. Only those cheaters who beat every fair player matter, none of the rest had any more or less impact than the fair players who also lost did. Also, by iterating, there is only ever one person falsely accused, every other accusation made is true, there are never any true or false negatives, nobody who impacted the outcome gets missed, nobody who had no impact is even bothered with, and I imagine the one false accusation made isn't going to annoy them too much since they are subsequently cleared and awarded the win every time. If everyone cheated, then I guess the best cheater wins? Dunno.

You neglected that there are other ways of optimizing to catch cheaters.  Certain patterns will appear more frequently- most obviously weighted coins will give you longer runs of heads or tails (depending on the weighting).  Though this is not the only possibility.  You could also look for a variety of patterns that appear more frequently under conditions of unfair coins- again, particularly the symmetric ones.  For instance, THTTT and TTTHT both occur with frequency 81/1024 given your assumptions, but only with frequency 1/32 = 32/1024 if the coins are fair.  So observing a particular run like this implies a likelihood of cheating.  There are more nuances to this method than the one you proposed, however.  For example- if you toss the coin 10 times, you are more likely to see that run in either the fair or unfair set of 10 flips.  Since you're doing this by simulation though and not calculating it from first principles, this methodology is actually no harder.

I would just like to point out that a 5% false positive probability is pretty terrible for a cheat detection system. Using such a huge proportion of cheaters in this example gives a slightly false impression of the method's efficacy. If we instead have 1000 players, where 5% are cheaters (50 players), the numbers are not very flattering. If we have a 5% probability of wrongfully accusing a legit player, then we will on average accuse 950*0.05 = 47.5 legit players of cheating, while only correctly accusing 50*0.8 = 40 real cheaters. Thus, 54% of the accused cheaters are actually legit. If we were to apply this to a real scenario, say, a competetive video game where a false-positive ban is generally considered completely unacceptable, then you can see why this would be a problem.
If you had the two curves without knowing the cheater coin, you'll get two peaks, therefore you could find the percentage of the cheater coin and adjust the test accordingly.

Maybe I'm getting ahead of myself, maybe I'm wrong, but it feels like we don't need to always flip coins the same number of times.

For example if we assume a 75% coin is being used by a cheater, there is a less than 2% chance their first three flips are all tails. 1/8th of the fair players will get tails on their first three flips, so we can pretty confidently send home 12.5% of our fair blobs and 1.5625% of our cheating blobs after only 3 flips.

Similar thresholds can be set for every number of flips less than 23 allowing us to reduce the number of coin flips we have to watch per blob to less than 23 in many cases. I may be back if I figure out what percentage of flips make it to 23, but I doubt it.

You can use the P-value for setting up a extra test rule. If the P-value is close to wrongly accusing a blob, than this certain blob has to do a few extra coin flips.

For example: The blobs where it's obvious if they are a cheater or not, due to a very low P-value, these blobs are done with the test after just 20 flips instead of 23 flips. Now this will take some time of the testing procedure of the detective. The blobs that are in the "not so sure range" (with a high P-value) they can perform extra flips in the detectives gained spare time.

This way the result gets even more reliable without increasing the total testing time for the detective.

This doesn't impact your test results because your test goals describe percentage of cheaters caught and percentage of fair accused independently. You could make your test goal a ratio, where you say 90% of banned are cheaters, and then that would have you been dependent on cheaters size. I wish more online PvP games actually went this far with anti-cheats. I've played many online games in the past where it definitely wouldn't have been out of the question to flag and monitor players who had extremely high levels of accuracy over many hours of play. People who use aimbots should theoretically be pretty easy to catch through the game's code alone, and not need third party anti-cheat protection or anything like that.

Just like with the heads/tails test, the game would monitor shooting accuracy over a long stretch of time. If the accuracy crosses clear over an unattainable threshold, the player can be banned. It isn't even a matter of catching every single player. Merely, the ones that are benefiting the most from cheating. Especially in games with leaderboards, monitoring the top players should always be done. Even if cheaters adjust the cheats to not be as accurate, there could be many other aspects of gameplay being monitored that can be totaled together to produce an overall "cheater score".

The goal isn't necessarily to ban every cheater... but to just force cheaters to lower their advantage to the point where they aren't any better than other players. Effectively canceling out the cheat, in a way. But with multiple detection systems in place, it's possible to ban every single cheater with enough data, while not banning a single fair player.

I think we could implement conditional testing to achieve our goal with less work, and likely decrease false positives and false negatives at the same time.

We could assume that blobs who get less than a certain number of heads over a certain number of flips are not cheaters, but then continue testing with more flips for those who don't meet that particularly-low-heads-flips criterion during testing. I think this would save us some unnecessary flips early during the test and allow us to use our saved time to do more flips for higher accuracy with the other blobs.

We could even do this in multiple stages, making cutoffs based on what number of fair players we can rule out with various heads:flips ratios.

I think your methods overlook a very important concept that is required to get a good score for your minigame. The designed system does not have to use the same number of flips for each blob. For example, if a blob gets 5 heads out of 5 flips, we could designate them as cheaters right away and keep testing if it got fewer flips. Such a method would work better in fulfilling another goal: "Make the total number of flips of all blobs as few as possible."

The method that I use, for the online game, is to keep flipping until either a blob has 6 more heads than tails (labelling it as a cheater) or both more than 6 heads and more than 6 tails (labelling it as fair). That seems to work well, for me, with the current iteration of the game.

Hypothesis testing is a great way to do this but you could also fit the data to a model and calculate the probability directly for each person.  Then for the parameter of your model, calculate the 95 percent confidence interval and if the probability and confidence interval capture .5 then they're not a cheater.  You can do this for all people and find which confidence interval captures 80 percent of the cheaters and 5 percent of the people.  This is equivalent really but if you're less familiar with hypothesis testing and more familiar with model fitting, it could be a good method for you.

What about tests that don't have a fixed number of coin flips, but the number depends on the incoming results? For example, we start with making the test subject make 10 coin flips, and if they get 5 or less heads, then we end the test right here and mark them as 'probably innocent'. However, if they get 6 or more heads, we continue the test and make them do 10 more coin flips. If they get 5 or less heads again they are marked as 'probably innocent', otherwise they have make another 10 coin flips. We have to stop at some point, so let's say that this third series of flips, if it comes to it, is decisive: if in that third series they get 5 or less heads they are marked as 'probably innocent', otherwise they are marked as 'probably a cheater'.

It was only my first proposition, but by my calculations it already gets very close to the goal. With the asumption that the cheater uses a coin with 75% heads rate, the test I described above has about 5.33% chance of falsely accusing an innocent, and 78.3% chance of recognizing a cheater. Additionaly, the average number of throws required untill we reach a verdict is 15.2 if the subject is innocent and 27.7 if the subject is a cheater, which makes the test less annoing for the innocent, and depending on the total number of cheaters, can even save the detective's time, as he spends less time with blobs he judges 'probably innocent' early.

What would it look like to have a two stage test in order to better achieve the third goal? For example, have a first test which you create to have confidence in catching at least 95% of the cheaters, and falsely accusing less than 40% of fair players. Then, once you have the field narrowed down, you could go back to the original 80%/5% goal. By quickly removing about half of the true fair players, you can more fully test the remaining players within the same total number of flips.

I think the best approach would have been a series of tests. If the results are >5/10 then they go on to second the test. This way everyone will be asked to flip at least ten times, but potential cheaters will be the only ones to flip more. With each test we then increase the flips until we reach the false positive rate of zero. Each one will also receive a marker saying how far in the tests they went. Still not perfect since cheaters can slip through by not getting more than half but this way the amount of false positives are miniscule and cheaters caught are at the max. This also accounts for variations in coin odds, meaning we'd still min/max the results even with a 51% coin.

You could improve things by applying more dynamic game logic for point 3 (Making the test as brief as possible). You would require extra 'cheater checking' flips but only for people who are seeming more likely to be a cheater than others.  You would not want to tell players which flip was for the game vs extra 'cheater checking' since they could use a different coin for those flips only. So the player wouldn't know which flip was which until after flipping. For example, say the game requires 20 flips. After each flip it would reevaluate who is more likely to be cheating and apply weighting that requires those people to continue flipping until 20+n.  (20 + n cheater checking flips). The more likely they are a cheater the more extra flips you make them do which gives you more data to use.   This would boost the ability to identify a cheater without requiring non-cheaters to perform many extra flips.

I feel like we could potentially increase the efficiency of finding cheaters by breaking up the test into many smaller runs rather than one long one at higher flip counts. The idea being to constantly rule out fair players who's most recent streak is less than 1% likely to be a cheater. This could allow for the total number of flips tracked to be lowered as you no longer need to track the ruled out players.

The issue here is that it may generate more false negatives, but it will likely also generate less false positives. After all, even if the cheater gets that 1/100 possible result in one of the testing rounds, they would have to go well above average in the other rounds to make up for it and what might be a 1% chance for a cheater will be a higher percent chance for normal players which would translate to about that percentage of regular players being removed from testing.

Perhaps there is a balance that could be struck here to allow for lower guessed cheater averages to maintain lower false positives while decreasing the total flips tracked. It also has the added benefit of working even if the actual cheater averages are higher, making the chances that a cheater gets marked as safe exponentially lower

I figured out a way to get 1% false positive chance, with ~64.2% of cheaters caught. I set the number of tests so that the total number of flipped coins is proportional to your 16/23 example, but cheaters will flip more coins than the fair players, on average.

Essentially you make each player perform the following game 8 times, averaging their score in the end.
The game is to flip a coin and every time you get heads, you get a point. When you get tails for the first time, the game ends.
50/50 players get 1 point on average, while 25/75 players get 3. (This is not relevant to my algo tho)

Afterwards, use k-means to split the players into two score groups. The group with lower average score is mostly fair.

My k-means n-flips game results are:
Out of 32586 suspected cheaters, only 32111 were cheaters. That is a 1.5% error rate.
Out of 67414 fair players, only 49497 were fair. That is a 26.6% error rate.
Out of 50028 cheaters, only 32111 were caught. That is a 64.2% success rate. Target is >80%.
Out of 49972 fair players, only 49497 were let go. That is a 99% success rate, or a 1% false positive rate. Target is <5%.
Cheaters flipped their coins 32 times on average, for a total of 1599551 flips.
Fair players flipped their coins 16 times on average, for a total of 801295 flips.
Total coins flipped 2400846 times.

Your 16/23 results are:
Out of 42619 suspected cheaters, only 40307 were cheaters. That is a 5.4% error rate.
Out of 57381 fair players, only 47650 were fair. That is a 17% error rate.
Out of 50038 cheaters, only 40307 were caught. That is a 80.6% success rate. Target is >80%.
Out of 49962 fair players, only 47650 were let go. That is a 95.4% success rate, or a 4.6% false positive rate. Target is <5%.
Cheaters flipped their coins 23 times on average, for a total of 1150874 flips.
Fair players flipped their coins 23 times on average, for a total of 1149126 flips.
Total coins flipped 2300000 times.

- Total score 4

Run 3:
- Same rules as Run 2

this reminds me of a post I saw on facebook that had like 20,000 likes about A college professor that had his 150 students go into a room full of balls that had their names on them and they had 5 minutes to find their own name. According to the post not a single one of them found their name, he then sent them in to grab a random name and give it to the persons whose name it was and they all had their names in under a minute... it was supposed to illustrate the importance of teamwork. That is an idiotic story and it makes me feel physically sick that so many goddamn people believed it. Even if we assume all the kids are blindly snatching at balls and only know when they grab their own (meaning they can grab the same ball twice), and also assuming the average student grabs 6 balls a minute, you would expect 20% OF THEM TO FIND THEIR OWN BALL... except wait the students who found their own ball would remove it from the experiment... MEANING EVEN MORE OF THEM WOULD HAVE FOUND THEIR OWN BALL. but assuming for the sake of easiness that the students throw there ball back into the room after finding it, making all events independant, The likelyhood of all the students finding their ball in 5 minutes with 6 grabs a minute is .13% meanwhile the likelyhood that nobody finds their own ball is 0.000000000008% with these assumptions (and yes even a small deviation from these assumptions would change these results alot but this is about proving a point not actually predicting the probability of a story somebody clearly made up) IT IS OVER 16 BILLION TIMES MORE LIKELY THAT EVERYONE FINDS THEIR BALL THAN NOBODY DOES AND THIS IS ASSUMING THAT PEOPLE DON'T ONLY GRAB FOR BALLS THAT LOOK LIKE IT COULD BE THEIR OWN NAME most people know shit all about basic statistics and it drives me up a wall. I commented "clearly he was not a probability professor." some people did the laughing emoji but must were like "what do you mean?!" and I commented "it is statistically impossible that this story is true unless the professor covered the first set of balls in names that none of his students actually had or something, (which would be a hilarious prank btw, fill a room of balls with names that none of your students actually have and tell them the first 10 people who find their name gets 10 bonus points on the final and see how long it takes for them to realize that none of their names are in the room.)

I love this so much! As a game dev I'm desperate for anti-cheat. However gameplay time can prove dedicated people to get really lucky and having 1% false positives means that there's a much higher chance that actual dedicated players get lucky and falsely accused. That's why I believe it shouldn't be as brief as possible, but be constantly looked at. Like a history of average luck over all flips and over the last few flips, if the player has been playing for some time then the test becomes less brief assuming that they'll be more consistent with what they're doing. They won't randomly enable a cheat so theit test is more forgivìng and catches far less cheating scenarios, but if the history sees a sudden spike of luck then that's a sign to be investigated.

What if you ran the 16/23 test, and if the test comes up negative, you let them go. If it's positive, though, you don't just stop after labeling them a cheater. Let them choose to keep flipping the coin to try to get a more innocent looking statistic.

Theoretically, this would let most of the negative blobs go without inconvenience, and it lets the positive blobs inconvenience themselves to provide more accurate data, a risk that all fair blobs and most cheaters would take to try and clear their name, right? Does that make sense?

Edit: you could try this with any coin flip ratio and it should theoretically work.

This is the third example today of problems arising from trying to parse a continuum of data into discrete categories. The difference with this one is that there are actually only two discrete categories to fit them into: cheater, or fair, player. But I think that calling that out still has value in the context of the question of "when do you call them a cheater" comes into focus. The answer is that you are never 100% certain, and you only gain more confidence with more data. Presumably asymptotic certainty vs time. Be happy in the knowledge that you will falsely accuse some people, and let some cheaters roam free, and use that knowledge to apportion their consequences accordingly.

Just 2 and a half mins in, and I already see an issue. The whole point of this exercise will be that cheaters want to cheat as much as possible to 'win'. This is something actual real intelligent cheaters do NOT want to do. Cause if they play a game and win 5 out of 5 times, they are of course cheating, and even tho they 'won' they are instantly spotted, kicked out, and lose their winnings and banned for life. Even people losing once to make it seem like luck, 4 wins out of 5 games, would still most likely be a cheater, trying to be 'smart' and make it seem like they lost one, so it isn't so clearly they can't be cheating, right? Wrong!

No, the most best cheater, wants to be the absolute most average. Not the most wins. They want to usually hover around 50% wins, 50% loses, tho not exactly that, to be seen as the most 'average' of player and believable. Sure, they might not win the best prize, but if they do this to collect 10 prizes? 100? 500? a million? Suddenly those earnings start racking up. And when your cheating, this can be easy to do.

Unless your playing a highly recorded video game, where they have all the data of your wins, loses, and what you did during the matches for every single event to look through, you will never be called out, unless you win 'too' fast for an 'average person' giving away your taking shortcuts through cheating. Generally, tho, no one ever records that much data, and even if they do, wouldn't care to sip on through all of it, all at once, looking for cheaters. They would look for people accused of cheating first, and then go through the accused's records then and only then to save time.

So when you shows the 6 people, the one in my eyes that showed the most likely hood of being a cheater, wasn't the 5 heads in a row, but the 3 heads and 2 tails, and the 2 head and 3 tails, as they were the most average, and most likely where a cheater would hide to not get caught but still win over time.

I had some crazy idea before I started watching. We will define heads to be 1 and tails -1. So the expectation value is zero, and to test whether someone is a cheater we will make him throw a coin a lot of times, some significant amount of trials. And then we just use the law of the big numbers, namely if someone is not a cheater we will expect his average to be close to the expectation value (say 99% close). I proposed a math based damage mod finder to a coder for a anti cheat plugin for battlefield 3.
BF3 had a problem of client-side hacks, this plugin targeted the people changing damage values.
Wasn't that hard as BF3 stats existed and logged shots fired, body parts hit, and so on.
So I found 2 dozen or so top level players who had just stupid amounts of time played and had no bans or other cheating flags from publicly available blacklists, in short, most guns did a max of 25 damage except for head shots, and my control, the high hour top players averaged 21-22 damage a shot for those 25 damage guns and 29(i think its been years) for the 34 damage guns(even with the 100 damage a head shot gets you).
The anti cheat plug in first checked if the played had at less 100 kills for each gun checked, then it went and just did simple math to see what there average damage per shot was per gun, and anything over 24/33(base gun damage -1) was flagged for manual review, anything over 26/35 instant ban.
The coder set it up in shadow mode on our most used server where It didn't auto ban anyone but basicly had the 2 flag levels (1 manual review 2 would have auto banned but for testing was the this flag needs to be as accurate as can be), and within 3 days of us checking all the flagged people, well it was 100% accurate those 3 days. We are talking 10s of thousands of players playing thos 3 days and only damage mods being flagged even on the manual review level, so coder guy he turned on the auto ban flag, and the admins suddenly had a lot less work to do lol, think we may have even lowered the manual review flag level to 23/32, and maybe changed from 100 kill min to 100 kill and 1k shots hit (there were other plugins for improbable accuracy rates).
Had 1 false positive in the 3 years it ran that i know of, the person in question, primarily played hardcore servers where you have 80% normal heath, we had him un banned the same day, and yes I was aware, and had made it know when the plugin first went up to the admins that this fringe case was possible but still statistically unlikely, and to always give someone appealing the benefit of the dought till you review the stats yourself, though I was the one who usually handled most of those appeals cause well i could type out the math and copy paste there states from BF3stats and close the appeal in under 3 min on a good day.
The one false positive i had to go 1 step further then normal and check match history and go, yup, this guy plays hardcore like 85% of the time, and as such the overall average is at the ban mark, but its only cause his overall damage is inflated by 20% less health from that much hardcore server time, and the game on our server in question was clearly within statistical limits.

Evolutionary biologist here. I've been using machine learning (neural networks) to predict a certain genetical modification, we had a lot of good data to train the model, and we achieved very good accuracy (over 90% both in positive and negative sets). However, we trained this model with a balanced datset, where we picked an equal number of positive and negative examples. The thing is that in reality, the positive result is much rarer than the negative (something like 40 times rarer). When we tested our model on a dataset with the real frequencies, the statistical power and true negative rates were consistently over 90%, however, because of the frequency distribution of the data, we still had 5 times more false positives than true positives. So, yeah, you can have tests with great accuracy, but the frequency of the data you are working with can still make your results less than desirable.

Odd question, but how would you go about doing the reverse of this situation. A game tells you that you have a 25% chance of rolling heads, with each failed flip raising the chance by about 1%. however out of maybe the 50 flips you've performed, you've landed on heads a total of 5 times. How would you go about telling that a games chances are in actuality lower than stated, using the least amount of 'flips'.
Edit: And specifically working out a more accurate % chance of rolling heads, based on your own experience.

For about a decade now, I've described the Frequentist approach as God's Double Roulette.

Basically, you walk up to God's Casino and see Him with a bookie's hat at the roulette table but no wheel. You ask what this is about, and God says "You put money down, pick a percentage, say something, and then I spin a roulette wheel that says either true or false."

" 'A' roulette wheel?"

"Yup, see, if you say a false statement, I pick one wheel. If you say a true statement, I pick the other. But they look identical; you can't tell the difference. Funny enough, the true wheel always has the fixed percentage you choose of being false. However, the false wheel changes its probability depending on the question and how much money you put on the table. Now I will say that the more money you bet, the more likely the false wheel will come up false, but it's never 0. Oh, and if you ask another question, I put the wheel back beneath the table before selecting the appropriate one, even if it's the same one. No cheek at the table ;D"

"And they'll tell me whatever I say is true or false?"

"That's right,"

"Why can't you just tell me instead?"

"I've found people are more accepting what the wheel says than what I say. So, wanna give it a spin?"

The strategy you use to get any use out of the wheels is the same you use for doing studies. After some thought, you'll end up with just verifying a claim you already know to be true and then working your way from there, periodically verifying other claims in order to contradict a result. In other words, Frequentist hypothesis testing does not rely on trying to prove yourself wrong except every once in a while; it relies on having a long chain of verified results i.e. you are constantly trying to verify the null hypothesis, not looking to demonstrate the alternative hypothesis is in fact true.

Question:
Couldn't we refine the test by checking the clustering of heads?

A fair blob should get a somewhat equal distribution of heads and tails.
The cheater heads should be more clustered.
Like this (X is tails, O is heads)
Fair (O X X O O O X O X O O)
Cheater (O O O O X X O O O O X)

It's the same dataset, but a secondary metric.

The idea behind it is, that if you're above a certain threshold AND your heads are more clustered than it should be - you're probably cheating.
Type 1 and Type 2 error introduce new terms, but avoid the the ambiguity of true-negative, false-positive, false-negative, true-positive.

There's a flipside (hah) to how these coins are weighted, and the lesson you tried to teach us at the end. A cheater's coin coming closer to 50% heads reduces its chances of getting caught, but it also reduces the odds of winning individual flips, obviously. It's a risk assessment from their perspective as well! Do they want to really avoid getting accused? Cheat only a little bit, like 51-60% (or lower, technically, but then it's not really cheating.) Want to risk time in blob jail for that ultimate winstreak high? Go nuts, make a 80-100% weighted coin!

So yeah, the lesson is that it's hard to know for sure whether you're catching enough cheaters with your tests. But also consider that if more cheaters get away, it's probably because they weren't such a detriment to the coin flip meta to begin with.

One thing I would do to minimise the number of coin flips needed is to make it variable.
You keep 23 coin flips as "worst case", and - say - 5 coin flips as "best case, and set a threshold for each coin flip.
E.g.: 5 heads out of 5 -> cheater; 5 out of 6 -> cheater; ...; 16 out of 23 -> cheater.
This would achieve the goal, complicating the test but reducing the average number of coin flips needed to detect a cheater.
Conversely, once it's mathematically impossible for a blob to toss 16 heads out of 23 (i.e., it tossed 8 times tails), you can leave it alone immediately.

I love your video!  I have some quibbles with the math you used, though, as applied to the rules of the game.  Mainly, its just that the evaluation was not how most of us played the game.  We played given expected value.  Given all of the information we have in the game, there is a better equation to use.  If 50% of players are cheaters and cheaters get heads 75% of the time,.  Therefore, if we ran total expected 2048 tests, we would expect to get 324 4-0s  from the cheating half and 64 4-0s from the honest.  That means about 83.5% of the 40-s are from liars.  We had a -30 penalty from a false guess and a +15 bonus from a true guess.  That means that on average we add 7.577 guesses if we guess there.  So for it to make sense for us to make another guess, we would need to increase the average guesses earned to more than 8.577.  If we took one more guess, of the 392 4-0s, 275 would get a heads and 117 would get a tails.  On a yes you would accuse.  Of the 117 tails, 32 are from the honest and 85 are from liars.  If you weren't going to accuse before, you aren't going to accuse now.  All 117 require at least one more flip.  Actually, since 5-1 is less confident than 4-0 (and we've established 4-0 confidence isn't enough), all 117 need at least 2 more flips. If we guess at 6-1, we would be left with 37.1875 liars and 24 truth tellers, either at 5-3 or 6-2.  When you do all of the math out, you find that you should guess at 4-0 to maximize your expected value.

My immediate thought is not to look at percentage of heads/tails, but patterns of heads/tails sets. Assign values to the set results, and use that final value to make a judgement.
Example: Use sets of 3 flips. 3 heads is +1 ; 2 or more tails is -1. After five sets of 3, if their total is >x, accuse them, where x is whatever threshold of positive we think will be most accurate. Plenty of variations of this that may or may not work better, such as sets being defined by consecutive results rather than a fixed number - first set of flips is until they get 3 consecutive heads, or 2 consecutive tails, whichever comes first.
I am not going to spend the time to work out whatever variant or target number would be best to minimize test size, but I am confidant one of the variations of this system would be the best form of testing.

I know this is just trying to teach about stats, but lets take it serious for a bit ---
Mainly, this is another of many examples why statistics-first approaches for, well, anything, are a hindrance for any real-life scenario.
Imagine this coin game really did exist, and players were going to a "coin flip playground/tournament" that we supervise. We would have to somehow "test" every incoming player with this nonsense, and would still be getting into fights with many innocents who got falsely accused. A nightmare, a totalitarian system that will quickly turn people off from playing. Even accusing 1% would be ridiculous.
A real life approach wouldn't even bother with statistics - as it should be: Statistics should only be used to confirm/deny the fundamentals, the theory, the qualitative approach - not the other way around. Trying to find some way to "justify" your statistic through a theory is a great way of screwing up both. Meanwhile, confirming or denying an internally-logical theory through statistical means is a great way of advancing knowledge.

A real life approach would first wait for someone to get accused by another player who felt wronged: that gets rid of unnecessary work (if everyone had fun, who even cares), unwarranted work (dont need to test everyone), and thus allows for more time spend on each case. Also, because catching a cheater implies some action to be done to the cheater (banning them from playing, taking their coin away etc.), you would always have to document each of these cases and communicate the results to some official/game-master - documentation can often be more time-consuming than actual tests, so cutting down the number of tests is the first priority.
Also, having a specific test set up for everyone simply allows a cheater to only cheat when nobody is looking. A cheater would try to circumvent your test, perhaps by using another coin - they cannot do that if they get accused by a credible player during or after a game, and then have to prove their actual game-coin is unbiased on the spot.

A real life approach would also want to mainly concern themselves with patterns of psychological behavior, not statistics:
Does someone not want to share their coin with others? Does someone avoid having their coin touched by others, especially game officials? Does someone avoid playing with pro players, always trying to crush newer or inexperienced players? Does someone use weird tricks during play?
Testing for these factors and talking to the accused player about their weird behavior could get a confession out of someone quicker than any test setup, and allows the option of having someones coin be banned quickly without banning the player. It also allows a potential cheater to "save face" and return to being a normal player with an unmodified coin, without any further work.

Even after having someone be accused officially, a real life approach would rather test physical reality than statistics: They would weigh the coin, test its balance, and see if it deviates from the usual standard model (was it modified? made at home?). If the coin is 100% standard-issue, but still deviates from the norm, that is actually really important information for the coin manufacturer, and also for the other players: maybe there are others who unintentionally "cheat" because they got the badly-manufactured coin. So, you should test that first, not the statistics.

See what I mean? Statistics can confirm or deny the information these other approaches produce, but it cannot replace them. That still means statistics are useful, but you should never start anything by thinking about statistics: You should start by thinking about the fundamentals, about qualitative science. Then comes statistics. Not the other way around - far too many statistics nowadays get misused, misinterpreted, wrongly used to create too broad conclusions, etc. etc. because they get wildly thrown around without any proper non-statistics theoretical foundation.

For cheaters specifically, visual-mathematical patterns (non-cheaters might produce very unlikely outcomes as well, but their timing is usually different, more random) and psychological patterns (trying to get attention, "winner-types", player who hit their skill boundary and get frustrated by luck, etc.) are usually way more useful to start out with, to then confirm your suspicions with more testing.
You should not try to catch someone with statistics alone, unless you really have to, and the odds are so overwhelming there is basically no other option but for the accused to be a cheater.

Take the case of Dream, a minecraft cheater into account: statistics were used to confirm him as cheater, but the results were utterly overwhelming against him. However, psychological behavior and the mathematical pattern of consistency were just as convincing.
Far more usual however, are cases such as the Trackmania cheating scandal, which was not exposed by statistics (because thats not really possible in most cases), but rather through technological analysis of how the game was played.
From a human communication perspective, offer to swap coins with the suspected cheater and let their reaction to that request add weight to the mathematical probability.

The irony of this being a simple example is that it's actually very hard to find cheaters in a timely manner. Because we're just looking at the probability of a single event, it takes a lot of flips to determine variance, no matter how fancy the math gets. But, Machine-Learning based anti-cheat in videos games would have a much easier time doing their jobs at finding cheaters after very few (or even just 1) instances of cheating because actions in a video game are so complex and go by very quickly. No matter how fancy the algorithm, it wouldn't be able to reliably find a cheater in this game until a couple dozen attempts at cheating have gone by.

in this particular example, you could have run a first test and plotted all the results on a graph, and (if all the cheaters use the same coin) you would have seen the 2 spikes, telling you the probability of the biased coin as well as how many cheaters/fair players there are (by comparing the amplitude of the spikes), so you can design your test accordingly.
Alternatively, if all the cheaters used different coins, since you can assume nobody uses a coin that gives you a disadvantage you can use the results below 50% heads to give you an estimate about how many blobs play fair. With that you can remove the fair players from the statistic, leaving you with the cheaters. Now you dont know who individually they are but you can design your test more precisely to catch them.

I wish you'd talked about what happens when most of the population is fair and there's only a handful of cheaters. In that case you end up accusing way more innocent people than guilty ones even if you set the false positive % very low. This is a very poor outcome. Unless you follow up accusations with another, more powerful test examining the coin itself to know for sure if it's fair. The followup test is more disruptive and probably more expensive so the purpose of the first test is to minimize the number of followup tests needed. In such a situation the first priority of the first test should probably be minimizing false negatives. It's inconvenient for the false positives to have to get another test to prove their innocence, so you still want to try and minimize false positives too, but you want to catch as many of the cheaters as possible.

There’s a good riddle that uses this problem, where you have to face someone who is using a biased coin that lands either heads or tails more often, but the way to make it truely random is flip the coin twice. If it comes up heads then tails assign that as ‘1’ and if it comes up tails then heads, assign it ‘0’. Ignore flips that land either both heads or tails and you have a perfectly random system, no matter how biased the coin is.

In Moral Foundations Theory there is an assumption that liberals and conservatives all have moral values, but the emphasis that they place on each value varies. Liberals, on average, tend to be more worried about not punishing someone who doesn't deserve to be punished, and conservatives, on average, are more likely to want to make sure anyone who is cheating is caught.

It would be interesting to see what thresholds self identified liberals and conservatives decided to set the thresholds at. For happiness I'd think a big difference in value would be very important, but in a gambling system you really just need a big enough edge to continuously grow your pot of money. As a liberal, if I was designing this test, and there wasn't a way to just passively collect the results to look for statistical outliers (so, basically, you only got to see the results when the detective was actually looking), I would move on from anyone who seemed to be using a fair coin fairly quickly, but extend the test when they seemed to be using an unfair coin to help rule out false positives. Basically, I'd give them an extra number of flips to see if they regressed towards the norm, in which case I wouldn't accuse them, but the more flips we saw on the suspected cheaters the more likely we'd see conclusive evidence that they were cheating. (Assuming they don't get wise and palm the coin and switch it out for a fair one!)

It would be interesting... you could, of course, do the opposite... accuse fairly aggressively and then continue to monitor to start to catch the cheaters who just had a run of flips go against them. Like I said, it would be really interesting, if you presented this without sample numbers to self identified liberals and conservatives, to see where they'd set the thresholds, and, if they figured out the way to get more confidence by expanding the test for certain individuals, which group they were likely to extend the test for.

Here's the optimal method with a variable number of flips:

Basically

Classify as cheater:
0 tails: ≥3 heads
1 tails: ≥5 heads
2 tails: ≥7 heads
3-5 tails: ≥9 heads

Classify as fair:
0 heads: ≥2 tails
1-2 heads: ≥3 tails
3 heads: ≥4 tails
4-5 heads: ≥5 tails
6-8 heads: ≥6 tails


This is using the assumption that 50% were fair and the other 50% were using a 75% coin and that the bonus for correctly classifying is +15 flips and the penalty for incorrectly classifying is -30 flips.

For the intuition behind how to find it. We start with the probability of 50% that they're a cheater and 50% fair. Then every head amplifies the odds of being a cheater by 75% ÷ 50% = 1.5 and every tails amplifies the odds of being fair by 50% ÷ 25% = 2.

Using this we can find the probability our decision is correct to tell when there's a higher EV for asking for another flip or making a decision now.

Great video, but I want to point out one thing:
the true proportions are also very important. Let's say you have 1000 blobs, and only 10 cheaters. With a 5%/80% test you would get 50 false positive, and 8 true positive. So only ~14% of the accused cheaters are actually cheaters.
In the real world big factors for the limits of such tests are the consequences: What happens to a patient with a false negative test? Will he die soon (eg. cancer), or will he just stay two days longer sick at home?
And what happens with false positive test results? Will the person go to jail (eg. drug test), or undergo harsh medical treatment (eg. chemotherapy), or will he just take a day off?
In praxis these issues are often solved by confirming the results with additional, different tests (in case of the blobs the manipulated coins might have a different weight...), but should still be considered, because these tests again have the same problems, and every additional test costs money and time.

I didn't get caught out by the assumption pitfall because I thought "if I were a cheater, how would I break the test?" and immediately landed on "use a bias closer to 60%, I still get to cheat but I'm very unlikely to get caught" ;)

I actually went through and calculated my own method for the game (75% heads for cheaters, 15 more flips to use when correct, 30 less when wrong) and found the average benefit from stopping and declaring cheater or fair. The main benefit of this is that it tested not just for cheaters, but for fair players as well, since it would be absurd for a cheater to get 5 tails in a row. This also made my decisions much more brief since there's much less overlap on the lower end. This also has the benefit of being able to calculate at set positions, so I wouldn't have to spend as much time making a flip, checking my table, and so on.
If the cheaters had various different strengths of weighted coins, then this test would be more likely to catch the cheaters who had more strongly weighted coins.

Haven't finished the video but I feel like the actual value to maximize is the difference between false positive and true positive. So you're not trying to catch as many cheaters as possible and you're not trying to avoid as many fair player as possible, but you're trying to minimize the portion of fair player caught compared to cheater.

That means the test needs to adjust based on the population of cheater. If there is a high number of cheater then it needs to be more sensitive, but if there is a low number of cheaters then having too many false positive is bad because at this point you're ending up catching innocent people for low results. Like, if there is only 1% of cheaters and you have a 4% false positive rate then you're having more false positive than cheaters and you might aswell not try to catch those cheaters at all even if you're below the 5% false positive line because you're doing more harm than good. (of course you can keep monitoring cheaters to see if thee lack of sanctions has negative effects on the cheater rate which force you to implement sanctions back again).

Of course in real life you'd need to also weight the prejudice caused both by cheaters and by wrongfully accusing someone. For exemple with the death penalty, the cost of wrongfully accusing an innocent is extremely high, actually typically much higher than not catching someone.
On the other hand if you're tracking a serial killer and all you know is that they have a red car with a bloody hatchet in it, then sure you'll probably get a lot of false positive by checking every red car but it's only a minor inconvenience for the persons involved so it's worth it, though that kind of exemple isn't ideal cause you get into the questions of trusting instiutions, mass surveillance etc.

A better exemple might be vaccines, that are extremely worth it in case of very dangerous diseases because they'll be a minor inconvenience for many that wouldn't have caught it (false positive) but the cost of someone who'd catch it not being vaccinated is very high. On the other hand the milder the disease get (and the less it spreads efficiently) the more the minor side effect associated with the vaccine would start outweighing the benefits of stopping the people who'd get sick from catching the disease.

I went through a whole programing journey to learn about what this video shows. when you first put up the coin flipping game I tested for a little bit and the cheaters I tested came up heads about 75% of the time and since that seemed like a nice number that you would pick, I decided to run with that assumption. I programed a replica of your game (with the assumption that half of the blobs were cheaters and a cheaters coin would come up heads 75% of the time) and a robot to play it.

the robot would use some math akin to the binomial distribution function to determine the exact probability that a blob was a cheater given a certain number of heads and tails. for instance if a blob got 6 heads and 1 tails then there would be an 85% chance that it was a cheater.

after every flip the robot would tally up the heads and tails and calculate the probability of it being a cheater, then if the probability was above a certain threshold it would guess whether that blob was a cheater or fair, otherwise it would flip the coin again and repeat the process. so if I set that threshold at 80% the robot would guess only when it was 80% sure that it knew the correct answer, otherwise it would flip the coin and try again.

at this point I was confident in what I had programed so far, except I didn't know what to set that threshold at. so I made another simulation that would use the numbers from your game i.e. you use one flip every time you flip the coin, you gain 15 flips when you guess correctly, and you lose 30 flips if you guess incorrectly. then I had robots with all different thresholds in 1% increments play that simulation for 1 million round each and then show me how many flips they had at the end of it.

when i finally got the results back I was shocked to see that they all came out negative. all of the bots lost more flips than they gained. some thresholds worked better than others, the best threshold was somewhere about 73% but even that robot was not able to survive indefinitely. they would always run out of flips eventually.

I had been sure that you could go forever with the right strategy so I went back and tested to make sure that I got all my programing right, but it had. there were no bugs. out of curiosity I went back and started tweaking the variables about how many flips you lose or gain after a guess and to both my distress and amusement I discovered the if you were to change those numbers by the smallest amount, if you gained 16 flips for a correct guess and lost 32 for an incorrect one instead of 15 and 30, it became possible. with the right threshold you could play forever, never running out of flips, and always gaining more than you lost on average.

I came to the conclusion that you must have designed the game with that in mind. you didn't want people to get an infinite run, and so you made it impossible.

but when I looked at the leaderboards I saw the people had gotten runs with thousands of correct guesses so I made another solution using the 73% threshold and this time i made it play a real game so that it would loose whenever it got to zero flips. and as it turned out it wasn't too hard to get large runs, my strategy was almost good enough and every now and then it would get just a little bit lucky and achieve runs in the tens of thousands.

with all of this knowledge in hand I turned my attention towards building a bot to play your game, not my simulated version of your game but the actual game on the internet. it didn't work. I tried to make it look at the colors of certain pixels on the screen to discern what was happening but I could never get it to stop messing up every now and then and reading the screen incorrectly.

eventually I gave up, satisfied that I had at least learned the intricacy's of the mechanics of your game and saw what looked like a game intelligently designed to be almost but not quite possible to defeat. but after watching your video I must question my assumptions.

did the cheater coins really come up heads 75% of the time? was it 60%? or, horror of programming horrors, was the probability different for every cheaters coin? was my robot doomed to failure from the beginning even if I could have made it read the screen correctly? were my assumptions correct, or did I fall into the very trap the end of this video warns against?

I was disappointed at first, because I was hoping to see a guide to detecting cheaters when there are an unknown number of cheaters and an unknown probability of cheaters flipping heads (especially if the probably isn't the same among all cheaters). That would be particularly applicable to evaluating justice systems - what are the odds that someone is a criminal given that they're accused? We know some systems have absurdly high false positive rates ("witch hunts"), whereas e.g. the US system is supposed to produce low false positive rates ("innocent until proven guilty").

Hearing that Frequency Hypothesis Testing is commonly used in the real world explains why we got this instead of that. But since the FHT results are heavily skewed by their initial assumptions, it sounds like the tests aren't useful when there's too many unknowns. In other words, I'd only want to use FHT if I had some data going in - like the odds that a cheater will flip heads.

Possible improvements to this would be to add a second test that looks at the past coin results. There’s a phenomenon where people who pretend to flip a coin tend to be more evenly distributed whereas the people actually flipping a coin got a lot more similar results in a row. If you pair a test on yours that looks at past flips of the player and it has an extremely low rate of similar results in a row, then it will improve true positives on results where the cheater % is unknown.

Looking forward to the Bayesian vid - that would be my approach. A nice way to contrast the Bayesian vs frequentist perspective is that.. frequentists condition on the “true” parameter and integrate probabilities over the random data. Bayesians, on the other hand, condition on the data and integrate probabilities over the (assumed) distribution of the unknown parameter. To me, this makes the bayesian approach more attractive, because in reality, we only know the data - not the parameter.
